title: 112_s1194
content: The "Consular Notification Compliance Act of 2011" aims to facilitate compliance with the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations by providing consular notification and access rights. This Act is enacted under the authority of the United States Constitution. The Consular Notification Compliance Act of 2011 enforces consular notification rights for foreign nationals detained or arrested in the United States, in accordance with the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations. It mandates that arresting officers must inform non-US nationals of their right to notify their consulate. The Consular Notification Compliance Act of 2011 enforces consular notification rights for foreign nationals detained or arrested in the United States. It requires prompt notification to the individual's consulate upon request, and mandates notification under international agreements. If not previously notified, consulates must be informed before the individual's first court appearance. The Consular Notification Compliance Act of 2011 ensures foreign nationals detained in the US have the right to communicate with their consulate before their court appearance. Government officials must facilitate this communication, but no legal action can be taken against the US or its entities for any violations. The Consular Notification Compliance Act of 2011 allows foreign nationals in US detention to contact their consulate before court without legal action against US entities. SEC. 4. PETITION FOR REVIEW. Federal courts have jurisdiction to review petitions claiming violations of consular notification agreements for individuals sentenced to death before the enactment of this Act. A stay of execution may be granted if necessary for review. Relief is available under certain standards. To obtain relief, an individual must show actual prejudice to the criminal conviction or sentence due to a violation. The court may hold an evidentiary hearing if needed and, upon finding prejudice, must order a new trial or sentencing. A petition for review must be filed within 1 year of the enactment of the Act or the finalization of the court judgment against the individual. A petition for review under this section must be filed within 1 year of the enactment of the Act or the finalization of the court judgment against the individual. The time during which a properly filed application for State post-conviction review is pending shall not count towards the 1-year limitation period. The petition for review under this section must be filed within 1 year of the enactment of the Act or the final court judgment. It cannot be considered a second or successive habeas corpus application. The final order on a petition for review can be appealed to the court of appeals if a certificate of appealability is issued by a district or circuit judge. The appeal must show actual prejudice to the criminal conviction or sentence. The individual can raise a claim of violation of consular notification and access rights if facing a capital sentence, as per the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations. Upon finding a violation of consular notification and access rights, the detaining authority must immediately notify the individual's consulate and provide consular access in accordance with international agreements. The court may postpone proceedings as necessary to address the violation. The court may conduct evidentiary hearings if necessary to resolve factual issues and may enter orders to facilitate consular access and assistance, without creating any additional remedy. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "national of the United States" and "State" as specified in the Immigration and Nationality Act.
